Fields.DialogueText: I need Bulldog on the bridge. Has anyone seen her?
Somebody call my name?
Two things. First, I wanted to commend you on our recent battle. Phenomenal work.
Pleasure's mine.
Second, we'll be welcoming a visitor tomorrow: a war correspondent from The Daily Express.
We?
You don't look thrilled. What's wrong?
Oh, this tea's going to need some extra bite.

Fields.MenuText: Bulldog, what's the matter?
I insist on an answer, Bulldog.
Ignoring a direct question is insubordination, Bulldog.

Fields.DialogueText: It's nothing, Captain. I'm just wary of nonmilitary personnel being on board. Not ideal, is it?
Yes, Captain. I'm hesitating because... well, let's just say I'm not the biggest fan of civilians mucking about in military operations.
Apologies, Captain. I meant no disrespect. To be honest, the idea of civilians on board nerves me up.
Regardless, I'll expect you to be hospitable and helpful to our guest.
It's not me you'll have to worry about, Captain.
*ALARM*
We can discuss the details later. For now, action stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
I rest my case.
Welcome aboard, Mr. Reynolds! Lovely to have you with us.
Lovely to be here, Captain. I take it this is the bridge?
Right you are. Ah, allow me to introduce you to the lady of the house. Bulldog, this is Mr. Reynolds from The Daily Express. Mr. Reynolds, our resident Belle, Bulldog.
It's an honor to make the acquaintance of such a lovely creature. I must say, you are stunning.
That so?
Bulldog...
I beg your pardon. It's jolly good to meet you, Mr. Reynolds!
Likewise. I'm sure we'll get to know one another quite well.
Indeed. Captain, might I have a word with you? Alone?
Will you excuse us, Mr. Reynolds? The mess hall is just down the way. Have them whip you up something to eat.
Certainly, and thanks. I'm dying for a spot of tea.
I don't trust him, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Don't trust him? Why not?
You haven't even given him a chance. Get to know him before you judge him.
Regardless, I expect you to behave professionally.

Fields.DialogueText: Something in the way he looks at me. Both of me. Like he wants something. I'm a sound judge of character, Captain. But I'll carry out my duties regardless.
Perhaps you're right. There's just something... slimy about him. But I promise my opinions won't affect my work either way.
England expects that every man will do his duty, I suppose.
Good. Now, let's see if Mr. Reynolds would like a tour of the ship.
*ALARM*
We've got bigger problems right now. Action stations!
@BATTLE
The ship consents.
I dare say, this ship is remarkable! The crown jewel of our navy. Ah, Captain! We were just finishing a tour of this incredible vessel.
Lovely, isn't she? We run a tight ship, Mr. Reynolds, as I hope you'll communicate to your readers.
It's obvious you do. I'm sure my readers will find your story thrilling.
*ALARM*
Captain, enemies approaching!
Mr. Reynolds, have a seat. I think you'll enjoy this.
Captain, I hardly think that...
Not now, Bulldog. Commence attack!
@BATTLE
Got the blighters!
Truly remarkable! What an incredible woman you are, Bulldog!
Just doing my duty.
I had hoped you would use the battle as an opportunity to take notes, Mr. Reynolds.
Not to worry, Captain. I have a photographic memory! No detail escapes these five senses.

Fields.MenuText: You must be a top-flight journalist.
If I'd tried that excuse in primary school, I'd have gotten a rap on my knuckles with a ruler.
Well, so long as you write a compelling story...

Fields.DialogueText: Though to hear you say it makes me blush.
Years of schooling and experience, Captain. I'm no magician; just practiced.
This story will open eyes, Captain. That I can promise you.
Now, if you'll excuse me, all this excitement has left me famished.
Captain, with all due respect, permitting a civilian on the bridge during combat is inadvisable.
We'll discuss this later, Bulldog. In the meantime, see to it that Mr. Reynolds has everything he needs.
Wouldn't that be nice...
He's covered wars, Bulldog. He knows the risks.
Not against Morganas. Right, then, mask off. It's mad.
Captain on the bridge!
I'm glad I didn't miss the starting gun, so to speak.
Bulldog, if we have a moment or two after the battle...
You'll know where to find me, Captain.
@BATTLE
You wanted a word, Captain?
Yes, Bulldog. Excellent job out there today.
It's all thanks to these remarkable sailors. Without them, we'd be sunk.
Of course, but you've played a starring role in our victories.
Thank you.
... Was that all?
Not quite. I feel like we've been at odds lately, and I wanted to clear the air.
Clear away, Captain.
I understand you're uncomfortable hosting a civilian, but the work Mr. Reynolds is here to do is for the good of the country.
How so?

Fields.MenuText: Keeping the nation informed of the war effort is key to our success. And what better way to do so than with a reporter here in our midst?
The more attention the public pays to us, the more support we're likely to gain. More support equals more recruits.
It's the media's responsibility to keep the government and the military honest. We prove we have nothing to hide by welcoming them aboard.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose so... an informed populace and all that.
Certainly beats impressment.
Hmm. People do have the right to know what we're doing out here.
I'm glad you understand. Now, I've been meaning to ask... How are you at dominoes?
Captain, I'd say I'm bloody good. I'd be right, too.
You're on.
Can't afford to. This war's a three-legged race.
Fancy a scrap, Captain?
Slow ahead. They'll come to us.
@BATTLE
As you can see, our medical staff are highly skilled, and our injured sailors are treated with the utmost care and kindness.
Yes, clearly they are. Let me ask you, Miss Bulldog.
Just Bulldog.
Oh, we're dispensing with formalities already? Wonderful!
Fripperies, too. Your question?
Right you are. So, judging by the rattling of my brain and bones, we took a few hits in that last battle. Tell me, do you feel that as pain?
I am the ship, so yes, getting shelled hurts a little bit. I'm a big girl, though. I can handle it.
Of course you are, of course. Simply fascinating!
Let's remember our sailors too, Mr. Reynolds. I wouldn't want the focus solely on the lady.
I'm really not all that interesting.
I beg to differ! You're an astonishing work of art!
Quite.
But you're right, Captain. Might I interview a crew member and maybe a member of the medical staff?
Feel free. Just make sure to keep out of their way.
Absolutely. Thank you, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: A strange sort of fellow, isn't he?
"An astonishing work of art?"
You've got a real fan, Bulldog.

Fields.DialogueText: Strange, Captain? He's barmy! Can't imagine why anyone would be so obsessed with me. Besides the obvious.
Yes, I'm the prettiest girl out of Wallsend shipyard. Cabbage-headed git.
Ugh. That's the last thing I need.
There's nothing wrong with having someone in your corner.
Pah. Mine's full.
Bulldog, report to the bridge immediately.
Yes, Captain?
We're overdue for a strategy meeting. I believe we need to...
Mr. Reynolds, hello.
Hello, Captain.
... As I was saying, Bulldog and I need to talk strategy. Very important stuff.
Excellent! This ought to spice up my piece. Carry on, then. I'm not even here.
This is classified stuff. Civilians are right out.
Is that so? I know for a fact that Brilliant's captain has held in-depth strategy talks with their correspondent. Good reporter, but a funny fellow...

Fields.MenuText: I'm afraid we do things a bit differently here, Mr. Reynolds.
The actions of other captains are by no means permission in my book, Mr. Reynolds!
I need you to leave the bridge now, Mr. Reynolds.

Fields.DialogueText: I see. Disappointing, but I will take my leave.
What a shame. That captain's openness with the press is commendable.
I see no need for such a harsh tone, Captain.
*ALARM*
It seems this discussion will have to wait. To your stations!
@BATTLE
Speaking of things brilliant...
Come again?
That's more or less the idea.
Mr. Reynolds, a word, please?
Of course, Captain.
About our conversation earlier, before that last engagement.
Ah, yes. I'm sorry about that.

Fields.MenuText: I want to clarify the boundaries here. On my ship, and especially on my bridge, my word is law.
You are here as a guest, and you will follow my orders without question. Bulldog's, too.
One more breach of security and we part ways at the next port. Understood?

Fields.DialogueText: We're perfectly clear, Captain. I let my zeal for a good story overwhelm my better judgment. It won't happen again.
My profoundest apologies, Captain. I understand the privilege you've extended to me quite well.
Of course. It was a lapse in judgment on my part. I do apologize.
Good. Glad to hear it.
While I have you, I was wondering if I might interview the lady of the house at some point. I'd like to get to the bottom of her story.
I suppose that could be arranged. I'll find a time that works and let you know.
Oh. I was hoping I might... if it might be possible to... interview her alone?
I'm afraid not, Mr. Reynolds. I can't allow you unfettered access at this point. Why on earth would you need-
*ALARM*
We'll discuss this later. For now, take shelter!
@BATTLE
Another time, then!
You can come out now.
Finally. I was starting to think he'd never leave.
You could at least say hello now and again.
I'd rather shag one of those Morganas.
Heart of oak are our ships, jolly tars are our men. We always are ready. Steady boys, steady! We'll fight and we'll conquer again and again!
You've a lovely voice, Bulldog, but is there a chance you could sing more quietly? Or better yet, somewhere else?
Apologies, Captain. I thought the general mood could use a boost. And once I get going about the Empire's wooden wall, well, there's no holding my voice back.
Admirable, but also loud. Very loud.
Of course. Sorry to disturb, everyone.
You know who might enjoy your singing at every volume? Mr. Reynolds.
Ugh, no, thank you. I've had quite enough of him lately.
I think he might be sweet on you.
Captain! Is this appropriate bridge talk?

Fields.MenuText: I'd call it "bridge banter" myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Whatever you want to call it... ugh. No, thank you.
*ALARM*
Captain, they're coming back around!
Blast it. Relentless, aren't they?
We'll take care of 'em, eh, Captain? Ohhhhh... Heart of oak are our ships, jolly tars are our men...
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What's the worst that could happen talking to him?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm a Belle, so not much. But he could put me right off my dinner and that's quite enough for me.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. I should be setting a better example.

Fields.DialogueText: And that is why you are my captain. You know where you end and I begin.
Innit, though?
An unstoppable force singing about an immovable object.
Captain?
Captain!
Ah. Sorry, trying to squeeze in a spot of exercise.

Fields.MenuText: How are you finding your accommodations?
What can I do for you?
Staying out of trouble, Mr. Reynolds?

Fields.DialogueText: Everything is quite comfortable, at least as much as can be expected on a warship. Captain, I was wondering...
I'm glad I caught you, Captain. Is this a good time to chat?
Doing my best to, Captain. Do you have a moment?
What can I help you with?
My readers are very passionate about Bulldog. It's easy to see why, of course, especially having met her myself.
She's an excellent sailor, and an excellent ship besides.
Excellent, indeed. My question for you is this:
How human is she?
How human? Not at all. She's a warship.
No, I mean, I understand that much, but... I've seen her in the mess hall, and she appears to eat and drink like anyone else.
That she does. When she wants to.
Fascinating! But beyond that, beyond the more... mechanical elements of humanity, does she... is she capable of... love?
What sort of question is that?
I assure you, it's something my readers will want to know.
That's something you'd have to ask her, I'm afraid.
Not a problem. I'll do that. Perhaps at our interview, whenever you both have time. So long for now, Captain!
... Strange man.
@BATTLE
I am, incidentally.
Whoa! Bulldog, don't scare me like that.
My hull, my rules. This is all going a bit funny, Captain. Any more questions like that and I'll be forced to assert myself.
I could be tempted to look the other way.
I've sensed some Morganas just now. Perhaps he'd be interested in an object lesson.
Bulldog? You look... uneasy.
Morganas are incoming, Captain. Shall we defer the conversation until they're destroyed?
Makes sense to me.
@BATTLE
Captain, I have some disturbing news to report.
What is it, Bulldog?
I've been trying to find a classified dossier - something containing a few points of interest about German troop movements. I have to conclude that it's not just misfiled. It's gone missing.
Are you serious? When did this happen?
Sometime between last night and now. You and I went through the files, and then I returned them to the secure cabinet.
Are you sure?
I'm bloody well sure!... Sorry, Captain, didn't mean to-
It's fine. We need to find out who's behind this.
Captain... I hate to say it, but...
But what? Out with it!
Last night on our way out, I saw Mr. Reynolds in the hall. He waved at me, in fact, so I know he saw us leaving.
What would you have me do?
Captain, I believe we should place him in custody. Just until we can get to the bottom of this. After all, he's the only unvetted person on board.

Fields.MenuText: He was vetted, Bulldog. The Protection Force wouldn't have allowed him to board without vetting.
Are you sure this isn't personal? I know you've had... issues with Mr. Reynolds.
I don't know... I don't want to jump to conclusions.

Fields.DialogueText: But Captain, we've fought with these sailors! We know them! We don't know Mr. Reynolds, not really. And I refuse to believe one of ours would have scarpered off with classified information.
I promise you, Captain, my personal feelings have nothing to do with this. I'm only looking out for the best interests of the ship and crew.
Think of it as a precautionary measure for now. Until we have more information.
... Very well. Have Mr. Reynolds placed in custody.
With too much pleasure.
I hope this isn't a mistake...
Hello, Mr. Reynolds.
I hope you're comfortable, circumstances aside.
I'm afraid I don't understand why I'm in here, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: This is a temporary measure. Some classified information has gone missing, and until we determine its whereabouts, we need to take precautions.
You're under arrest on suspicion of theft.
Admit it! We know you stole the dossier.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I must say, I'm quite put out. But winnow the variables, I suppose.
And what is it I'm supposed to have stolen?
I did no such thing! Wherever is this coming from?
The truth will out soon enough.
I would have keelhauled him.
Down, Bulldog. We must follow protocol.
Hang protocol! Intelligence leaks aren't any less leaky for it. There's something about him. He's not trustworthy. I just know it.
I can't run this ship based solely on your intuition. Let me handle this the way it must be. And not another word about it.
*ALARM*
You're the boss. Action stations, sailors! Let's move!
@BATTLE
The situation is classified. You'll be treated as a guest and restricted to your quarters until it's resolved.
I must object, given that my life and livelihood are on the line.
What are you doing, Bulldog?
Oh! Captain, I didn't hear you come in. I'm reading.
Really? You don't strike me as much of a bookworm.
Hey, I read! I read all the time.
The lady doth protest too much, methinks.
O, but she'll keep her word.
Point taken. What are you reading, then?
Nothing.
Nothing?
... It's a book on interpersonal relationships. I feel that... you and I have butted heads because I'm not great at... well, at communicating.

Fields.MenuText: Nonsense, Bulldog. Even people who've known each other for ages butt heads from time to time. There's nothing strange about that at all.
I'm glad you've decided to better yourself. Self-improvement is difficult, but it's something we all must do.
If you'd only follow my orders without pushing back, we wouldn't have to butt heads.

Fields.DialogueText: That's kind of you to say, Captain, but I do have a lot to learn.
I'm eager to improve at, well, everything.
I'm sorry, Captain. I don't mean to be insubordinate for the sake of it.
Well, if you come across any useful advice, I'd love to hear it.
*ALARM*
"Trust, but verify" lurches obtrusively to mind. As do our friends from the depths.
@BATTLE
Captain? Hang on a tick...yes.
Morganas at four o'clock. Feel it in my bones.
Thank you, Bulldog. Let's move to intercept.
@BATTLE
Captain, you should see this.
What's that? Hmm...
What's wrong, Captain?
The dossier was found...
What a relief! Where was it?
In Able Rate Jensen's bunk.
Wha... what on earth...?
I'd like Mr. Reynolds freed from the brig and shown to my quarters straight away. And take Able Rate Jensen into custody immediately.
Yes, Captain!
I... I can't believe it.

Fields.MenuText: I'm surprised too. Shocked, frankly. But Bulldog, this is why you should give people the benefit of the doubt.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Yes, I suppose so.
I'll be in my quarters, extending Mr. Reynolds our heartfelt apology. Hopefully he won't take it too hard.
Hmph. Throw him a triumph while you're at it.
... Do Belles have bones?
We do if I bloody well say so.

Fields.MenuText: Don't take this so hard, Bulldog. We couldn't have known.
I can't believe there's an innocent man in the brig.

Fields.DialogueText: We bloody well could have, Captain. I was just too blind to see it.
Somehow, Captain, neither can I.
Mr. Reynolds, please accept our sincerest apologies.
I'm afraid you were caught up in some nasty business through no fault of your own.
It's quite all right, Captain. These things happen in the fog of war, eh?

Fields.MenuText: Still, I'm ashamed they happened on my ship.
I'd appreciate the chance to make it up to you.
I hope this won't negatively impact your portrayal of us.

Fields.DialogueText: Like I said, it's quite all right. I hold no one to blame except the scoundrel who stole the file.
No need, Captain. You were just doing your job.
Absolutely not, Captain. I'm a professional, and I assure you, I'm as objective as the King is British.
Now, I was hoping we might sit down for our interview. I'm scheduled to depart the ship before too long, and I'd hate to miss the opportunity.
Ah yes, of course. I haven't forgotten. It's just been so hectic. We'll schedule a time very soon.
Captain, if I may... It's clear that you're incredibly busy. Might it be simpler for me to sit down with Bulldog for a brief talk? It will keep me out of your hair.
I'm sorry. I don't mean to step out of bounds, it's just...
Fine. You may schedule a brief interview with Bulldog. But please wait until we're docked. At sea there's far too much that demands her attention.
Thank you, Captain! I greatly appreciate it.
*ALARM*
Don't give me that look.
Oh, I'll go along with it. Permission to voice displeasure?
Granted.
Voiced. Consider it a recurring request.
@BATTLE
Until?
I haven't entirely ruled out keelhauling. Right, then, let's have some sanctioned violence!
To be perfectly frank, Mr. Reynolds, and no disrespect intended, but I don't feel comfortable talking alone with you. I'd much rather we speak in the company of the captain.
But Bulldog, I spoke to... Ah, Captain! Here, please, tell her what you told me.
It's true. I did give him my permission to interview you.
Lack of permission isn't the part I'm having trouble with, Captain. It wasn't yours to give.
I don't understand. I thought we were all getting along so well!
Mr. Reynolds, could you excuse us for a minute?

Fields.MenuText: Don't you think we owe it to him? After throwing him in the brig on mere suspicion?

Fields.DialogueText: ... If you order me to do it, I'll do it. But I really don't want to, Captain.
I won't order you. If you really don't feel comfortable, then decline. But I ask that you think about it. Give him the benefit of the doubt.
Understood. Thank you, Captain.
*ALARM*
Never a moment's rest...
After you, Captain.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We both agreed this was important. He's already got enough to say about his treatment here.

Fields.DialogueText: If he's the type to complain about hurt feelings in the midst of an apocalypse, I daresay he could use some apocalypsing.

Fields.MenuText: Is there nothing that will convince you to lighten up on him?

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing ladylike.
*ALARM*
Tell me the rest of the fleet is in good order, Bulldog.
Matching pace and aiming for the face. We're ready, Captain.
Very good.
@BATTLE
Captain, we have wounded men on deck!
Tend to the injured! All nonessential personnel to the deck immediately!
Bulldog, what's the situation?
We're moving the injured to sick bay. And...
Yes?
Mr. Reynolds is up there. Assisting.
Really? What do you mean?
He heard the announcement. Even though he was told not to, he risked his life to run out and bring several sailors inside.
Incredible. Foolish, yes, but incredibly brave.
The enemy has retreated, Captain. All clear.
Thank you, Officer.

Fields.MenuText: What are you thinking, Bulldog?
Are you okay? You look rather pale.
We owe Mr. Reynolds a debt of gratitude.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm wondering if I may have misjudged Mr. Reynolds. To selflessly risk his life like that...
I just feel guilty. I'd do the same in his position. For any one of my crew, I would... and we locked him away.
Or something resembling one.
I think... I think I'll grant him that interview after all.
You're sure?
I'm bloody well not. But I'm unsure of a fair few things lately. What's one more misjudgment?
Where on earth could she be... ?
Oh, Bulldog! And Mr. Reynolds. Funny seeing you two here together.
Hello, Captain! Just grabbing a late bite to eat. Had to dictate a story over the radio to my editor, which took far longer than anticipated.
I hope this isn't the fabled interview? I asked that you wait until we were docked for that.
Not at all, Captain.
I joined him, in fact. He's perfectly innocent of our appearance here together.

Fields.MenuText: I see. Well, I'm glad you two are starting to get along.
I didn't get a chance to thank you for your assistance with the injured. A reckless thing to do, but very brave.
Do I sense some sparks here? A budding romance, perhaps?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I think we're becoming fast friends, Captain.
Please, Captain. The opportunity to serve my country is all the thanks I need.
Ah, well, dear me... I hadn't come aboard with that intention, of course, although--
Okay then. I think I might grab a bite to eat myself. I've been-
*ALARM*
Foiled again.
Come on, Captain. I've got a tin of biscuits in my room. I'll share them once we've taken care of business.
@BATTLE
Shan't.
No, definitely not.
Steady on, now.
Stay sharp, Captain. There's a lot riding on this battle.
Don't overthink it. It's an engagement like any other.
@BATTLE
Come in, Bulldog. Nice job out there today. Now, are you ready to lose?
Lose? Please, Captain, I'm five-and-zero. I'm a dominoes champion. I can't be beaten.
Ah, but this time, I won't hold back!
Blimey, you promise?
So, I've noticed you've been spending a lot of time with Mr. Reynolds lately.
I suppose I have been, yes.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you've put the negativity behind you.
I assume he's being a perfect gentleman.
I think Bulldog's got a little crush on the newspaperman...

Fields.DialogueText: Largely. Turns out my instincts were wrong for a change.
Oh, absolutely, Captain. And if he weren't, well, let's just say he'd be taking a swim in the ocean courtesy of my left foot.
Not bloody likely. One word about protesting ladies and I'm emancipating myself.
I think he might have a small crush on you, in any case.
You think so?
Just a hunch.
Why Captain, you sound a tad jealous...
... Sorry, Captain. That wasn't proper.
No, I should be apologizing. You made your point.
Except for the part where you owe me a dominoes rematch later. You've got to win at something today.
Ha ha. It'll be your victory too, you know.
Ship wins ties.
Captain, I don't know how to tell you this, but...
But what? Out with it!
Another dossier has gone missing. And Able Rate Jensen is still in the brig.
*ALARM*
Blast. Everyone to your stations! We'll have to deal with this when we're not fighting for our lives.
@BATTLE
I heard the news, Captain.
If Able Rate Jensen is already in the brig, it means one of two things. Either we've been infiltrated by multiple foreign agents. Or...
I don't believe it was Mr. Reynolds, Captain.
I don't want to believe it either, Bulldog, but what's more likely: that a fleet of ne'er-do-wells has snuck aboard our ship in the guise of our sailors, or...?
Or that perhaps we were right the first time, and Mr. Reynolds is behind it after all.
I think he's got a good heart, even if he is a bit funny. And between you and me, he couldn't steal flowers from a meadow.
Listen, Bulldog. I've learned to trust your judgment. If you believe in Mr. Reynolds, I'll defer to you.
Thank you, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think we should do?
I'm at my wits' end. We need to take action, now!
Someone's head is going to roll for this. How can we catch them?

Fields.DialogueText: We should increase security around our files. I'll even take a shift personally.
Let's post an active guard until this mess is cleared up.
I'll make a point to monitor the comings and goings more closely. We'll catch the culprit, Captain.
Thank you, Bulldog.
Of course. And, Captain?
Yes?
Thank you for trusting me. It means a lot.
My pleasure.
Your alibi checks out. I appreciate your willingness to cooperate. You may return to your post.
Thank you, Captain.
Hmm...
Captain?

Fields.MenuText: What can I do for you, Bulldog?
This is a bad time.
Can't you see I'm busy, Bulldog?

Fields.DialogueText: I wanted to check in on how the investigation is going.
Apologies, Captain. I only wanted to make sure you were okay.
Beg pardon, Captain. I'd only intended to see if you needed anything.
The Naval Protection Force has given me a limited time frame to sort this out. If I can't, I could lose my command.
That's bloody ridiculous, if you don't mind my saying so. You're a stand-up captain.
Thank you for saying that.
Have you spoken with everyone?
Yes. Everyone except Mr. Reynolds...
... I see.
I'll have to speak with him. You understand that, don't you? Even if we've been wrong about him before, we can't afford to leave stones unturned.
Of course. I...
*ALARM*
Quickly, let's go!
@BATTLE
Of course. I'm sorry. Things are very tense.
Guns standing by to blaze.
They're so close I can smell them, Captain.
Good. I want them cleared off before they cause any more trouble.
And have the crew keep their eyes peeled for irregularities around the ship. You know what I mean.
Too well.
Another file missing. This is getting ridiculous! If we had any doubt before, it's clear now there's a spy in our midst.
What do you want me to do, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I need you here on the bridge, Bulldog. I have a feeling...

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
Confound it! More?
They're keeping their distance, Captain. But there may be more on the way...
I see. Communications, radio to base and tell them we need reinforcements!
On it, Captain!
I'll be right back!
Wait, Bull...

Fields.MenuText: Those razors aren't just for show, are they?

Fields.DialogueText: I try to save them for the Morganas, Captain. Against my baser instincts, mind.
I've a feeling we oughtn't entirely rule out feelings.

Fields.MenuText: Treat everyone as a threat until this is solved. Even me.

Fields.DialogueText: I picked you for a reason, Captain. You wouldn't make me regret it. You couldn't.
@BATTLE
Sweeping the quarters. No better time than before a dustup, when everyone's shouting and running about.
Let me know what you find.
Here's what I don't understand: how is the spy getting information off the ship? We haven't been to port in ages.
Perhaps by radio, Captain?
We monitor all frequencies, and the regular radio operators have solid alibis.
Then why didn't you-
Mr. Reynolds? What on earth for?
He dictates his stories to his editor at the newspaper. I overheard a bit. Really dry stuff, Captain. Not award-winning journalism, if you ask me.

Fields.MenuText: Hmm... I wonder...

Fields.DialogueText: ... Captain?
Escort Mr. Reynolds to the bridge. I'd like a word with him.
Yes, Captain, ma'am. I'll...
*ALARM*
Belay that order for now, Officer. To your stations!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We can't rule it out, but we can't act just yet.

Fields.DialogueText: It's getting serious, Captain. The crew are starting to look at each other funny.

Fields.MenuText: What kind of stuff?

Fields.DialogueText: Weather and animal behavior, mostly. Always thought he was an odd one.
They're not.
What?
Getting information off the ship. I found that first tranche of documents in my quarters. Rather neatly stacked, too.
I'm a literal embodiment of God, King, and country. You think I wouldn't have told you as soon as I found them?
Then maybe they wanted to send us a message. Maybe they got what they needed from those documents already.
Has anyone else been in my radio room?
Well, there is the journalist...
Several.
There you are, Bulldog. And Mr. Reynolds. I need a word with-- Hold on, what are you doing?
He's got a gun, Captain! Get back!
You are truly a noble and heroic creature, Bulldog, to stand between a gun and your captain. I was right about you.
I can't believe it, Mr. Reynolds! I defended you! I thought you were a decent man!
I am a decent man, my dear. That's why I'm going to save you!
Save her? What are you on about?
My contacts are on their way as we speak. They'll kill everyone on board. But they won't sink the ship. No, they'll commandeer it for their fleet.
And then, you and me, Bulldog-- we can be together. You won't be chained to this fool of a captain any longer.
You've got to be bloody joking.
You sent coded messages by radio. You weren't speaking with your "editor" at all.
Finally putting the pieces together, eh, Captain? The espionage was a ruse all along. All my people needed to know was your patrol route, and the game was ours.

Fields.MenuText: You're a traitor to your country.
You disgust me.
You're in love with Bulldog?

Fields.DialogueText: Patriotism is laughably quaint in these end times, wouldn't you agree?
I'd say the feeling is mutual.
What I feel for Bulldog is deeper than love. It's adoration. She is perfection itself...the future.
Shall I take him down, Captain?
Kill me, and my contacts send you to the sea floor, my dear.
*ALARM*
Git. We've scarier things to worry about than whoever lines your pockets.
@BATTLE
He's disarmed! Grab it, Bulldog!
Hyaa! Stupid blighter. Captain, any chance we can set decorum aside for a moment? I'd love to call him some more colorful names...
There's no need now, with your gun trained on him. Lieutenant Holden!
How...?

Fields.MenuText: Take Mr. Reynolds into custody.
Throw Mr. Reynolds in the brig straightaway!

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain!
I'm sorry, Captain. His charm clouded my judgment. I can't believe I was taken in by that manky bucket of--
No, I'm the one who should apologize, Bulldog. You were suspicious of Mr. Reynolds from the start. I should have trusted your intuition.
No hard feelings. I should have trusted it too.
Judging by the smoke on the horizon, I'm willing to bet those Morganas laid waste to Reynolds' contacts on their way to us.
Looks as if they did us a favor.

Fields.MenuText: Have him keelhauled.

Fields.DialogueText: Um... Captain?
The captain's having a laugh. Take Mr. Reynolds to the brig before I join in.
Of course. Yes, Captain!
You've my permission to treat him roughly.
Yes, Captain!
And really put your back into it when you do.
No good deed goes unpunished, eh? Let's mop up.
@BATTLE
Come in.
Ah, Bulldog. Good to see you.
Thought you might like a game after all this fighting.
That sounds marvelous.
So you'll have some shore leave while I'm patched. Any big plans?

Fields.MenuText: I might go to the theatre. Haven't been in quite some time.

Fields.DialogueText: The theatre, eh? That's not really my cup of tea, but to each their own.
I don't mind sticking around, you know.
I'd follow you to the ends of the earth, Captain, as far as I can go. You know you don't have to do the same.
With any luck, we won't have to go that far. This war will end, and things will settle down.
Yes, well... I'm sure that sounds good to a normal person, but to me...
What is it?
If I'm not fighting, then what am I doing in port? I can't leave the ship to go out and explore the world on my own. I'm a warship. When we're away from the war, I'm-
Intuitive. Inspiring. Not to mention a wicked hand at dominoes.
Captain...
You rise to whatever challenge rears its head, whether it's spies, Morganas, or a pint of something strong.
Now that sounds like a smashing way to spend an evening. Join me?

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to. One of these days I'll pull out a win.
Sure. And maybe... tomorrow evening as well?
Think I'll catch a rugby match.

Fields.DialogueText: Rugby?! I adore rugby! Ooh, to be able to go for a match...

Fields.MenuText: I was thinking I'd stay aboard with you.

Fields.DialogueText: Stay aboard... with me? Why on earth would you do that?
I suppose it'd be hard to get you into a seat.
Unless we dragged the New Shakespeare Company out onto the docks.
I'll never get tired of seeing you try.
I reckon I can live with that. I might even enjoy it.
